div.head: Letter From William Slany (Director, Historian’s Office) to Kenneth McDonald (Historian, CIA)
div.p: Dear Ken:

You and I have talked on several occasions recently about the nature of the future relationship between the Department of State’s historians and those of your agency. We have also exchanged information on methods used by Department historians to document the relationship between intelligence and foreign policy for published volumes of the Foreign Relations series. Foreign Relations, 1952-1954, volume X Iran, 1951-1954, published last year and widely debated recently in the academic arena, is an example of such a volume.

Let me briefly outline the circumstances of preparing the Iran volume. This volume is one of the most serious victims of the changing sensitivities in American foreign policy. The documentation included in the volume was originally compiled as (a) a separate 1951 compilation on Iran intended for inclusion in a larger 1951 volume and (b) a 1952-1954 volume planned as part of the larger triennium of 16 volumes. The original manuscripts were prepared between 14 and 16 years ago during the last major wave of accelerated compilation by the Department historians. Like so many of the volumes compiled in the mid and late 1970s and early 1980s, they made little progress in the declassification process during the early 1980s.

The 1951 compilation on Iran was eventually combined with the 1952-1954 volume on Iran to form a unique (for the Foreign Relations series) 4-year volume covering the years 1951-1954. This volume became a victim of the special nature of U.S. policy toward Iran during the hostage crisis. By 1985, it was one of more than 40 volumes in the slow moving declassification pipeline. It was in fact not in the pipeline, but on the shelf pending some significant change in the difficult relationship between the United States and Iran.

The documentation on Iran for the 1951-1954 period was compiled on the basis of these guidelines for Foreign Relations documentary historians that were operative 10 years ago. The documenting of intelligence activities and covert intelligence operations was considered a possibility and was actively pursued, but no access to the records of the CIA was accorded to Department historians. During the preparation of the compilations on Iran in the mid-1970s, the then CIA Historian provided Department historians with 37 pages of classified agency documents that effectively summarized events attending the overthrow of Prime Minister Mosadeq. These, together with some scattered records found in various State Department files, were included in the manuscript for the 1951-1954 volume.

Department historians visited with CIA in the late 1970s to explore and develop agreed terms of reference regarding the official disclosure policy for intelligence documents. Agency officials were not able to offer any historians’ access to Agency historical records, and they explained the prohibitions to the acknowledgement of intelligence activities in foreign countries, even when previously disclosed unofficially by ex-officials or unintentionally included in government documents and publications. This was at a time that the agency had no historians.

No high-level State Department appeal was made to challenge these CIA historical access policies. The special overtones of U.S. relations with Iran during the 1980s not only brought about the extended suspension of declassification action on the proposed 1951-1954 volume, but cast a pall over further research and expansion or revision of the existing manuscript despite some significant unofficial disclosures during the 1980s about the overthrow of the Mosadeq regime in 1953.

Once a decision was reached in the late 1980s to go forward with the publication of the Iran volume, declassification proceeded briskly. Most documents on covert operations in Iran that had been found in Department files or provided by the CIA historian were denied declassification when referred to the CIA.

The question of whether to go forward with the publication of the manuscript despite the exclusion of most of the evidence of U.S. involvement in or knowledge of the overthrow of the Mosadeq regime was discussed in the Department in 1988. Six principal considerations were identified:

list.item: 1. The decision to allow the Iran volume to be published was perhaps a short-term one and subject to reversal at any moment; it was necessary to act swiftly to publish a volume that included an important body of documents on Iran-U.S. relations.

2. Although CIA denied declassification of several critical documents, a few significant allusions remained in the cleared manuscript, and all scholars interested in the Iran area already shared the conventional wisdom about the U.S. role in 1953.

3. Without access to the complete CIA historical record, it was impossible for Department historians to decide whether the omission of the handful of documents denied declassification by the CIA distorted actual U.S. policies in 1953.
4. Agency declassification policies and attitudes toward acknowledging covert activities had not changed at all during the decade. No additional or new access or disclosure was possible.

5. One strongly held view among Department officials was that a challenge to Agency declassification policies would negatively impact upon other appeals of Foreign Relations volumes more likely to be resolved in a positive manner.

6. CIA was not alone in refusing to agree to the disclosure of documents in the Iran volume. A foreign government objected to the publication of its documents in the volume, and declassification of other documents was withheld by the Department itself.

div.p: Under the circumstances the Department historians concluded that the Iran volume should be published as it was before anything happened to close the “window of opportunity”.

The volume was duly released in 1989. But not without misgivings among the historians of the Department. With these misgivings in mind, I invited Prof. Bruce Kuniholm to review the volume for the Department’s Advisory Committee on Historical Diplomatic Documentation at its November 1989 meeting. Prof. Kuniholm was invited because he was a scholar-expert on the area and also, perhaps just as importantly, he had served in an important State Department position during the Iran hostage crisis of 1979-1980 and was familiar with the historical documentary record on Iran.

You are already aware of Prof. Kuniholm’s negative evaluation of the Iran volume. He took it upon himself to publish in the spring 1990 AHA Perspectives, a version of the review that he gave the Advisory Committee privately in November 1989. He did not ask me about it beforehand or afterward. I never anticipated that he would “go public” with his private analysis for the Committee and the Department. Prof. Cohen’s resignation from the Advisory Committee in February and Prof. Kuniholm’s publication of his analysis in March effectively took the issue out of the Advisory Committee channel before we here in the Department could do anything about the Iran volume. It is almost ironic that the Iran volume that was a prisoner of the state of U.S.-Iran relations in the 1980s became a prisoner again in 1990, this time of the dispute sparked by Warren Cohen’s resignation between the scholarly community and the government. In any case the Advisory Committee won’t be able to make its own evaluation of the issue before its annual meeting in November, and may not even have time to take it up then.
For my part I see a few possible courses of action to deal with the widely perceived defects of the Iran volume:

list.item: 1. We in the Historian’s Office could publish an article describing the circumstances and premises attending the preparation of the volume. The article, which would include much of the information cited above, could be published in several historical journals, including those of organizations represented on the Advisory Committee.
2. The Department could be asked to revise its longstanding policies and declassify some of its own documentation on the issues not accurately or adequately documented in the 1951-1954 Iran volume.

3. The Department and your Agency could devise a joint statement on Foreign Relations access and declassification guidelines for intelligence documentation. Such a statement could be published separately and/or included in the prefaces of future volumes of the Foreign Relations series.

div.p: The proper response to academic user concern about the Foreign Relations volume on Iran is one aspect of the larger question of how, in the future, to assure the comprehensiveness and accuracy of the historical documentation published by the Department of State. Among the proposals that are being considered within the Department is a request to agencies, including your own, to work closely with Department historians in both the planning and the access stages of the preparation of future Foreign Relations volumes. In particular this would mean that other agency historians could, during the planning of particular volumes or the designing of the overall scope of the series, alert Department compilers/editors to the existence of issues or bodies of documents that deserve special attention.

As an alternative to the very difficult task of working out access for Department historians at some of the more security-conscious agencies such as your own, historians of these agencies could be charged with responsibility for collecting from their agency files those documents that deserve consideration for inclusion in Foreign Relations volumes. Such a selection would be based, hopefully, on some constructive interplay between the agency historians and the Department Historian. Finally, the agency historians would be expected to help serve as advocates with agency declassifiers in securing a timely and favorable declassification review of the documentation finally selected for Foreign Relations volumes.

The preceding proposal is not yet Department policy, but may become so in September. There is a long way to go until such an idea is coordinated among all interested agencies. Some version of such a proposal may already have manifested itself in revisions of the proposed Congressional legislation for the Foreign Relations series. You and I may wish to work out ourselves some agreed language that would meet the need for greater access for Foreign Relations historians and the realistic possibilities for what you and your agency could do in terms of expanded disclosure of historical information.

I must not conclude this letter without reminding you of the great strides you and I and our staffs have made in developing strong cooperation ties. Access for Department historians to intelligence documentation has steadily expanded and been facilitated, since you and your staff have taken up your tasks. I believe we both are particularly pleased with the progress made by Tom Thorne, the former Deputy Director of the Department’s Bureau of Intelligence Research, in completing the projected Foreign Relations volume on intelligence and foreign policy in the 1945-1951 period. The excellent support Tom Thorne has received in compiling agency documentation augers well for the future.
I hope this has been helpful to you.
Yours Truly,
William Z. Slany
